qas.question: Along with Austrasia and Neustria, what kingdom was originally part of the Frankish kingdom?
From whom did the rulers of the Merovingian dynasty trace their ancestry?
What was the title of Pippin?
What leader was victorious at the Battle of Poitiers?

context: The Frankish kingdom in northern Gaul split into kingdoms called Austrasia, Neustria, and <a0_0>Burgundy<a0_0/> during the 6th and 7th centuries, all of them ruled by the <a1_0>Merovingian<a1_0/> dynasty, who were descended from <a2_0>Clovis<a2_0/>. The 7th century was a tumultuous period of wars between Austrasia and Neustria. Such warfare was exploited by Pippin (d. 640), the <a3_0>Mayor of the Palace<a3_0/> for Austrasia who became the power behind the Austrasian throne. Later members of his family inherited the office, acting as advisers and regents. One of his descendants, <a4_0>Charles Martel<a4_0/> (d. 741), won the Battle of Poitiers in 732, halting the advance of Muslim armies across the Pyrenees.[K] Great Britain was divided into small states dominated by the kingdoms of Northumbria, Mercia, Wessex, and East Anglia, which were descended from the Anglo-Saxon invaders. Smaller kingdoms in present-day Wales and Scotland were still under the control of the native Britons and Picts. Ireland was divided into even smaller political units, usually known as tribal kingdoms, under the control of kings. There were perhaps as many as 150 local kings in Ireland, of varying importance.
